comment: Nose was a bit medicinal with a sweet grass aroma. Butterscotch and apple were present on the palate, opens up with a few drops of cold water. Finish was long, smooth and creamy. Thick with notes of honey and brown sugar. Paired well with an Undercrown Dogma cigar.
at the Whiskey Room in Burlington...Cat lived it.

It is a rare after summer rain evening I tried it to relax. Though indoors, it tasted like sweet roses first, then smokey and woody-peaty...
Hoping for cork cappings used soon, I am in love with Jameson's 15 or 12 yrs old as it was not very known yet until Professor James Burke talked about it in his TV series, out of the blue! Since then, year after year, it became a luck to find them at duty free shops for me. 
Thanks to my husband Sam for CASKMATE.
Long live Ireland! Worepsauj Adigexer!
Good. Jameson with a bit fuller taste.  A bit of sweetness at the end.  Like it.
Slightly sharper flavor than traditional Jameson, with spice notes and a deep mellow caramel flavor.
Pleasantly tasty with interesting flavor and low burn. I've never been much for Irish whiskey, but I'd add this to my collection.
Smooth with cocoa notes appearing mid-tongue. Drinks smooth, finishes clean.
Wonderful!  A close 5 star.   A must have to restock.  Second go around  was nice.  Not the original 4.75 I gave it but close.   I  like the chocolate and fairly long finish.
Darker looks with a sweeter finish.

One unique taste! Vanilla,pear,caramel, vanilla cake in nose. Levender note, brown sugar, cream candy, floral notes in taste..wow! The finish is floral with a bitter feel, a shy nutty flavour also. The finish is similar a brown beer.
Unique smokey flavor for an Irish whiskey
This is like an upgraded regular Jameson, much fuller and richer. It's even more smooth can you believe it!? I will need to investigate this one better by getting a bottle!
Delicious; the smoothness of Jameson enhanced with subtle roasted sweetness of my favorite beer style.
Unremarkable. Fades into nothing almost instantly
A personal favorite. Creamy buttery biscuits.

Color: I normally don't talk about the color of a whiskey, but I thought it was cool the effect the barrell had on the whiskey. So the color is noticeably darker as an almost orange instead of the classic golden straw of standard Jameson. The stout that was present before it really must've altered everything a little.

Nose: On the nose your memory instantly welcomes back the classic familiar Jameson. Breakfast biscuits, citrus fruit, and honey all are present; but dark chocolate and malt are added too, with notes of sweet candy.

Taste: The palate is so good! The mouthfeel is so smooth and creamy. I tasted honey, what reminded me of Whoppers malt balls, some not unpleasant bitter hops, and milk chocolate on the short finish. I don't know why exactly, probably the creaminess and enjoyment found in this drink, but after a sip I'm also reminded of a cappuccino or caffe breve. 

Opinion: I have absolutely nothing bad to say about this whiskey! I love everything about it, from its smell to its taste, to its origins from a cool partnership! I'm a big fan and I would definitely buy it again! Sláinte!
Best Irish whiskey I've tasted yet.

Nose: Malt, raisins, brown sugar, cereal, light oak, sherry. Very much like regular Jameson, but with everything turned up one notch. Enhanced maltiness is the most notable characteristic, and a dash of water reveals a little hint of the stout cask aroma.

Palate: Soft and silky, a malty arrival with chocolate notes. A sweet cereal hint appears in the development which becomes creamy rather than silky as it unfolds. Good texture overall and a dash of water brings out some hidden sweetness.

Finish: Short. Very faintly spicy and dry as it fades out, leaving a final impression as of mocha coffee.

A pleasant and successful variant of Jameson where the stout cask finish enhances the malty quality of the distillate considerably, but at the cost of some of the delicate citrus and fruity notes normally found in Jameson. It's a relatively subtle effect and although others have remarked how much it tastes of stout I didn't really get that impression. If anything, the stout cask finish gives this a profile slightly like a Speyside malt rather than an Irish blend.

Adding a dash of water makes it very smooth and easy to drink, but sacrifices a tad of the presence - note also that it's very easy to drown so if watering all you need is a few drops.

"Above Average" : 3 stars
lots of cocoa, chocolate, gingerbread spice. excellent on the rocks. as it melts, citrus and sugar cookie.
The stout really stands out adding an extra complexity to the Jameson. Stout bitterness with a dry mouthfeel in the finish. Plenty of spice.
Really like this. Maybe fav Jameson. Sweet. Love stout flavor

This was disappointing. I’d tried what I assume must’ve been the first batch, it had the same label as shown in the picture whereas the current label is black with white lettering. That batch had a nice influence from the stout casks that really came across on the palette and especially the finish. This new batch is severely lacking in that regard. It tastes like Jameson but there’s next to no stout notes to be found anywhere. I’ll be keeping my eye open for a bottle from the first go-round but avoid the current batch.
Not much of a flavor profile. However, it goes down smooth.
Dark Chocolate, Nutty, Moderate Spiciness with a quick fading finish.
Pretty good. Not too much stout flavour in it, but pairs really well with pizza and wings. Definitely my favourite Irish yet.
Very nice body and a soft after taste. Most worthwhile.
Chocolate, barrel aged beer on the nose. Smooth with a slight chocolate bitterness on the pallet.
Pas si mal mais on feel le Burn! Considérant le prix c’est pas pire pr contre !

Even for those like me who find regular Jameson a pleasant if mild libation that simply does the job while being nothing to write home about, this is far too interesting a concoction to pass up trying.  And glad I am that I did. 

The afore mentioned "pleasant" Jameson nose is accented with spicy floral and sweet notes.   A very nice start. 

Up front this is rich(far richer than plain jane James) and the malt mocha and sweet dark sugars jump out, I get just hints of citrus and rose  wrapped in bold spice and chocolate,  this is not entirely unlike a Black Bush variant minus it's notable cereals. 

On the backside the butterscotch smoothness kicks in and only a hint of the stout brew cask is left to remind the barley lovers in us that this was actually enhanced in a beer cask and not just over barleyed on the mash side.   This is really an enjoyable treat and break from the tradition of plain old Irish and makes the caskmate concept a worthy choice, I find it far superior to the IPA edition and would heartily recommend this for the traditional whiskey bourbon drinkers bucket list. 

Like the other Jamesons, this one retains the smoothness and lack of heat, making it an incredibly easy straight drinker.  A well done one off and great change up for the Jameson  lineup.
rich, sweet with notes of white chocolate
Although light in color it has a nice dark flavor to it. excellent buy. i got this one for $20US!
Wonderful chocolatey nose. Very light taste still with the chocolate from the stout throughout

Picked up a 200ml bottle on impulse when checking out at the ABC the other day. After trying and enjoying the Caskmate IPA Edition this had been on my radar for a while. It was mentioned in another review that there were two different label designs. FWIW, my label looks like the picture featured on this site.
*Nose (Glencairn): Unique nose! The Stout is front and center with chocolate, honeycomb, malt, vanilla, wet hay and a floral note. When reviewing the IPA edition, most of my notes were "hints of" or "light". You won't see those much in this review as the notes of this one are bold and heavy.
*Neat (Glencairn): Whoah, this is sweet! Like an overly rich dessert. Heavy mouthfeel. Chocolate, honey, mocha coffee, and butterscotch are all present. The Stout barrel really imparts a ton of flavor. It ends with no burn and a bitter beery finish. Bitter dark chocolate and black pepper coat and linger. After a few moments a medicinal note similar to prescription cough syrup began to creep in.

Verdict: While I did like this one, it was a little too sweet for me. There is A LOT going on here, and none of it is subtle. I think I might be in the minority here in preferring the IPA version and it's lighter notes, even though I don't really like IPA's and do enjoy the occasional pint of Stout. Go figure...

Smells of chocolate and mossy grains

Tastes of smooth malty spice followed by hints of dark coco.

Drank straight up in glass.
Flavour has lots of punch neat!
Apples, vanilla and a touch of caramel on the nose. Nice golden colour, maybe a touch of coffee on the finish.
One of my favorite sipping whiskeys and one that I prefer neat with just a splash of water.
This is rated high in richness. I would say that, but it is good and the description is fairly good.
This is rated high in richness. I would say that, but it is good and the description is fairly good.
Astringent and sour with a ton of burn. Not mellow.
Smooth with a hint of a bite
touch of stout malt in the nose.  Rounder and slightly smoother than regular Jamo.  slightly nuttier.

Nose: vanilla, mildew, honey.
Palate: malt, chocolate, orange. Finish was short and warming.
Water balanced the nose but brought forward some sour citrus off-notes.
Overall: not too bad, a fun variation.
Loving this whiskey, getting shortbread covered chocolate this time and a little of green apple.

To note, this is my first Irish Whiskey. 
A super smooth whisky, it's almost dangerously easy to drink. On the nose i'm getting a light chocolate smell, with a vanilla tail. It almost smells like an oily, slightly sour chocolate candy.
In the mouth, it almost tastes like i'm eating milk chocolate that's attacking my tongue. The aftertaste is unmistakably vanilla. 
I actually quite like this whiskey. It's reminded me of the Speyside, but with a richer body rather then fruity.
Smooth. Much richer than the normal Jameson. Lots of coffee and chocolate. Little sharp candy on the finish.

Not a fan at all. I don’t get the chocolate or coffee on the nose like others; I’m unfortunately getting a musky fishy smell. I taste very light milk chocolate but more on the finish, but not enough to enjoy. I was expecting a richness, but that didn’t come through even after sitting and adding a bit of water.
Very smooth, and a little sweeter than original Jameson.  Feels like an after dinner kind of dram.
$210 dollars less than glenmorangie signet but has that same smoothness and some of the chocolate taste not complex but really good at one amazing flavour #mustlovestout
Nice and smooth, I far prefer to most other scotch’s of a higher price
Coffee beans and malt. Round and short.

Vanilla and brown sugar on the nose.
Tastes sweet and oaky in the mouth. Vanilla through the finish as well. A nice alternative to classic Jameson.

Pretty rich aromas of milk chocolate, hint of cappuccino, faint paint/acetone notes, nice caramel backbone. There's a slight earthy hop flavor. Has a bit of a burn, pleasantly sweet, astringent & a little sour. The body is quite light with an oily texture. Not as roasty as I thought it would be. Maybe the version with 8 degrees will be more flavorful.

My first tasting of this whiskey. I found it very similar to regular Jameson. It was nice, but I was unable to get the richness suggested by others.

This came after a few pourings of Redbreast at home which may have spoiled it for me.

Having tried the IPA version of this one and keeping in my recent Irish Whiskey tasting tour, I took @Scott_E advice and gave this a try. He was spot on with his comments. 
1) This is better than the IPA caskmate
2) It's full of rich malty and dark chocolate notes.
Other than that you get the standard sweet Jameson profile. Unlike the IPA, this one to me is worth the extra coin. 
Would I buy a bottle? No
Would I be happy to receive as a gift? Sure
Would I buy another pour? You could do worse for the price. 
Cheers all!
Sweet and creamy; tastes like whiskey with condensed milk or maybe chocolate mousse. Superior to the IPA Caskmates
Still enjoy this whiskey, but the further threw the bottle the more i figured it out. Tastes and smells like dark chocolate covered shortbread.
Worlds better than standard Jameson. Very creamy and easy to drink.
This is almost a black Barrel lite.  It’s got notes of what seems like pot still doused in caramel, char and a hint of roast coffee.  A worthy experiment and priced adequately.
Love this version- smooth and imminently drinkable

I've had Jameson a lot, as many of us have at bars for shots. I like it and think it's a good sipping Irish but at $30 it is a little pricy for a base level name brand Irish. So I was skeptical trying their other whiskeys until I saw so many great reviews for this I couldn't resist. It was on sale and also came with a 50 mL Jameson original so I had an easy point of comparison. The Caskmates Stout is utterly fantastic and frankly dangerous to drink with friends. The stout barrel adds a layer of creaminess that smoothes out the original without adding heavy stout notes. I would know this because I'm a huge beer drinker and mostly dislike stouts, and I didn't taste stout up front. I think it just makes Jameson better, and you can sip on this like a heavy beer or wine and finish 2 oz pours in no time. Honestly I'd love to see this released as a cask strength version and see how crazy it gets.

I give it a 3 because of the value - 2.75 if it were only based on taste. Certainly goes down smoother than regular Jameson but I didn’t get enough of the richness of the stout barrels. It worked well neat, but might have to give this one a shot on the rocks next

Nose: Biscuit with Butter, Chocolate, Rich, slight coffee

Taste: Creamy, Chocolate, Butter, Smooth

Great nose.  Glencarin glass with 2 cubes.  

Smooth with a cocoa taste.
Very smooth. Initial burn on the lips but smoother in subsequent sips. Nice overall.
Tastes like Jamo but a little less sweet.  I prefer the black barrelnor original but it’s a good mix up.  Some more malt comes through on this one. But not bad.
Flavor is muted, almost tastes watered down.

AROMA/ Fresh Oak, Vanilla, Slight Fruit, Slight Banana, Fading Berry, Slightest Caramel
FIRST SIP/ Sweet notes, Smooth, Oils, Slightist Spice, Caramel, Lingering Sweetness
TASTE/ Bourbon barrel aged Stout flavors, Smoothness, Woody, Woody Oak, Slight Spice, Slight Alcohol
FINISH/ Fruits, Woody smoothness, Oils on the pallet, Slight Vanilla, Caramel with lingering Spice
-This my friends is a straight up sipper! Pour it in a glass and sip it with friends! Sip it with friends and family that doubt the offerings that Jameson has to offer, this is the offering that changes your taste and will make you want more! I wood (typo intended) remind you these Stout barrels have many different characteristics and may (will) change and your taste buds might taste and react to this fine bottle differently than mine! DRINK WISELY & ENJOY Responsibly! This was a great find as I feel there's great inconsistency in the Jameson brand... others can be more consistent in flavors but this bottle is the pot of Gold @ the end of the Irish leprechaun's rainbow! Tell friends and family and enjoy this sweet Jameson find!
CHEERS!
very sweet choco coffee taste. short finish
Really nice for what it is. Super drinkable.
Caramel. Not bad. Worth a try
I’m confused by this. Seems like wood and a preface of stout halts the Irish whiskey flavors, but then nothing more is delivered but a bit o’ honey of hops. Nah.

My wife bought a bottle of the standard Jameson and it came with a miniature of both the stout and IPA editions of the Caskmates expressions, so I decided to do a side by side. 

The Stout Caskmates is the standard Jameson that is finished in casks that once held stout beer. It’s bottled at 40% ABV and is chill filtered and has colorant added making it a honey gold. 

The nose is very similar to the standard Jameson in that it has lots of honey, very malty and grainy. This version seems to be creamier than any other Jameson I’ve had. A very light oaky note, some light vanilla. The stout casks are not very dominant here but I do detect a roasted malt feel that is typical of dark stouts. A very light citrus note, fairly floral and a touch of butterscotch. 

The palate is better than the standard Jameson, less harsh with a darker feel to it. Cereal malt, fairly grainy with creamy vanilla. Butterscotch, very light lemon peel. The metallic note that I get in most Irish whiskies is still present here but is minimal. A touch of pepper. Fairly boring, but inoffensive. 

A light bodied mouthfeel that is creamy and mouthwatering. 
The finish is medium length, malty, some grain alcohol and vanilla. 

What can I say...it’s Jameson. This one is the same, only different. I would take this one if I had to pick a Jameson, but given the choice I’d rather not have to drink Jameson at all. I liked the nose on this one better than the IPA Edition, but I think I preferred the palate of the IPA to this one. For $33 it’s not terrible, but I’d rather get something else. 3.25
Cheers
Close to dethroning Woodford as my absolute favorite whiskey, now.
Light & creamy with chocolate and honey. Super smooth and easy to drink with only a little alcohol burn.

Nose: milk chocolate, almost fudge-like, slight coffee, cream and vanilla, light pear, butterscotch

Taste: unripened nectarines, chocolate, hops, butterscotch, oak, stout influence comes out in the finish

- chocolate
- stout
- wine 
- butter biscuits 
- rich oil
- apricot 
- fig
- butterscotch 
- nectarine
too smooth for its own good, not a lot of flavor
warm and full bodied, has a distinct stout note on the finish

Absolutely fantastic intro whisky for a newcomer. 
It’s gentle and sweet with very little burn or spice to scare your friend off. 

For the experienced it might seem a bit weak-sauce but a fun experiment and great value for money. 

Nose:
Lunchbox banana from an arms length away
Milk chocolate
Bright... creaming soda
Vanilla 

Taste:
Gentle stout influence with the young dark chocolate malt and dull mash hooping that appears on the breath out.
Super gentle on the palate, no alcohol burn or barrel spice to start.
Just sweet caramel and that brown banana again.
Tiny hint of coriander (cilantro) and mock green apple.

Finish:
A little spice and black tea lingers for a short time and vanishes.
It's a very light whiskey, not too challenging but definitely has some good stout notes. I get a little chocolatey coffee notes as well as maybe some vanilla. overall really good.

So I picked this up for St. Paddy’s Day because it’s about the only time of the year I go Irish - in whiskey anyway. Lots of positive talk/reviews of this one in some of the whiskey groups I frequent so I figured what the hell. Let’s give it a go shall we?

This version of Jameson is matured in “craft beer barrels” according to the label. Notice it doesn’t actually say “Stout” beer barrels, the name not withstanding. It’s bottled at the typical 40% ABV and is a nice medium gold in the glass. I expect it’s both colored and filtered. It leaves thin watery legs and not a few water droplets on the glass when you give it a swirl. 

The nose is pleasant enough with weak mild fruits, honey, and weak malty biscuits. Notice the word “weak”; it’s gonna come up a few more times before this review is over. 

The palate has light honey, butter, weak fruits, and no trace of Stout that I could discern. Definitely none of the coffee or chocolate notes that are typical in Stout. There is an odd flavor I couldn’t quite put my finger on. Not bad, just something I really couldn’t identify. Maybe that’s the influence of the beer barrels? Hops maybe?

The finish is short and the flavor I couldn’t identify carries through to the finish. Again, it’s not unpleasant, just different. Overall this isn’t a bad dram for $30. Its definitely drinkable if not memorable. 3/5. Sláinte!
Good cocoa flavor. Needs a splash of water to bring out more flavor
Smokey with hint of caramel/toffee sweetness and a nice spice on the finish.

Really sweet and smooth today. Quite nice. Have to revisit bottle at home. 

3/12/19
Whiskey school

Nose:  Sweet grain, toasted corn, a bit of nice spice, a rounded honey-like sweetness.  Searching for stout influence leads me to a chocolate malt note, not chocolate itself, but that dark note from toasted barley.  There's a vanilla milk-chocolate sweetness in the back too.

Palate: Light and watery at first.  Turns dark honey sweet with a surprising amount of light floral and a bit of citrus.  The stout is there in the back as well with a woody chocolate.  A bit of dark toffee with a coffee hint, then back to sweet dark honey.  Loads more chocolate-coffee stout influence now on the second go.  The stout hits mid-to-back-palate where it lingers on the way back of the tongue.

Finish:  Medium-short, slightly sweet.  Milk chocolate is the main lingering note.  Maybe a bit of peach too? odd.  Much more milk chocolate now that lingers way on the back of the tongue with a bit of woody vanilla.  

Conclusion:  At the first sip, I thought this was going to be pretty boring, but after giving it a little while to open up it changed completely.  So much chocolate now that I'd have a hard time drinking more than a small pour at a time.  I'd honestly prefer a little less sweetness, but I can also see why it is so sweet.  A pour of this for desert might be a good way to drink it.  I'm impressed, for a budget whiskey, this one's got some real complexity and character!
Een verrassende blend die samen met het eigengemaakte Ierse brood, een Ierse cheddar en een guinness special export stout een prachtige food pairing maakte!
creamy, chocolate, butter, like the usual low proof Irish mixed with Guinness

Nose: chocolate, hints of wood, and unsurprisingly, beer. Some faint honey as well.

Palate: coffee and dark chocolate. Slightly bitter. Some spice pound cake in there as well. Mouthfeel is moderately thick.

Finish. Dry and incredibly short. One of the shortest I’ve had in awhile. Not particularly complex. More wood and chocolate but you really have to search for it.

Overall: ABOVE AVERAGE. A decent upgrade from standard Jameson. If I had to have a bottle of Jameson in my collection, I would definitely choose one of their caskmates. As with most Irish whiskeys, it’s a good balance between a bourbon and a scotch, but it will
likely be replaced with a better Irish whiskey once the bottle is empty. Reasonably priced and readily available, this is an “everyday” Irish whiskey that could work well in cocktails and makes a semi-decent sipper on it’s own
clean, spice & oak, nutmeg. w/h20; melon, smooth w/frt
Meh. Not what I expected. Not bad though.
first Irish in a while, id like to try it side by side with standard Jameson...
Full. A real treat. Short finish and smooth. Could drink this all night.
Quite heavy mouthfeel, chocolate-y taste but still has the lighter Jameson finish.
I love the smooth Irish stout finish on this. Jameson up front, coffee and malt notes on the back end.

Smells like chocolate. Wonderful aroma. Has a deep sweetness to it with the grain. Big spike of burn separates the tail, which is more lingering chocolate. Love the taste on the finish. Stout adds a lot of character.
Very tasty and smoky. I really enjoyed it.
So smooth. Don’t really get the beer, but I am new to this.
Sweet, toasted nuts, thick caramel, mild chili pepper, a false Smokey flavor from the stout. Decent Irish expression.
The stout smooths out an already smooth Whiskey!

More round than the original and comes with aromas of vanilla, chocolate and berry. The flavors of butter, sweet cream and shortbread were fun but short lived. Worth the little extra price but still not exquisite.

Hint of Apple and dark beer on the nose. Tasting notes are similar to regular Jameson with an obvious mix of Stout. Adds an extra layer to normal Jameson. Small bite at the end but overall easy on the pallet.
This is okay, but nothing stellar. The stout finish gives the whiskey a much better flavor than the standard Jameson
Aroma: medium-low sweet notes with hints of malt, slight toastiness, faint dark chocolate and wood. Flavour: initial malt, followed by faint wood aged dark beer. medium-low wood note.
biscuity, sweet, rich and way way way too easy as a sipper.  it's dangerous.   you've been warned.
Not bad. I just taste Jameson, nothing different for me. I thought maybe the Stout would make it different, but not for me. Adding some ice makes it go down real nice.
fairly smooth and has a nice sweetness to it
faint smoke and coffee on the nose, very smooth and malty on the palate, sweet short finish
Sweet, round and a little overpowered by my scotch egg 😅
Very airy--almost as though it evaporates as sipping.
Nothing special on nose. Taste was normal Jameson  aka buttery plus added bitterness which could be the coffee/chocolate from the stout. Quick finish without much flavor. Don’t understand the hype.

The stout beer aromas are immediately apparent, with coffee, chocolate and vanilla with the typical Jameson aromas of orchard fruit and floral honey.  To the palate I find this one much more exciting, with the same flavours as the standard expression, but also layers of stout beer, dark hops, chocolate malt and hints of coffee layered on with a creamy texture that reminds of a frothy beer head.
—
Grain Mark:  80
Sweet and smooth. Tastes like hot cocoa with toasted marshmallows. Very pleasant warming on the finish. Very little on the nose.

Fuller bodied on the tongue. 
More fun to drink than the standard.

Color: light yellow
Nose: clean lemon with a hint of vanilla
Taste: lemon and cream. Very buttery and flaky. Ends in cream
It’s definitely more pleasant than Jameson’s basic blend, but not much better. It’s basically Jameson with a few chocolate notes thrown in. Still too sweet.
a mixed taste of bitter and sweet
chocolate finish, is the best part of this, asctone on the nose, but not in the taste

Very faint aroma, I have to really stick my nose in to smell it.  Has a floral scent.  Taste is initially vanilla turning to faint citrus, then caramel once swallowed.  Smooth finish.  A mild whiskey, but well balanced.
The most ginny whiskey ever. Sweet milk chocolate and juniper berries. Raisins and plums

Color: Dark gold.
Nose: Chocolate, banana, reminiscent of Balvenie Caribbean Cask. Water clouded it, made the banana stronger, and the stouty flavor came into the nose.
Taste: Light, banana. Water made the banana sweeter.
Finish: Strong, ethanol burn into stouty linger, short. Water made it smoother, though the stout flavor became muted and malt more prominent.

The nose is oatmeal shortbread with a little bit of cream and honey. Oak and caramel apple (like at Halloween) is fairly strong at the end of the nosing. This is really sweet on the taste, too sweet for me in a way that reminded me of simple syrup and only gives a little ground to the apple and honey. The interesting oatmeal on the nose is missing and this just tastes like a fairly generic Irish. The finish gets a little bit darker and I think I can begin to see the stout-influence but then it's over. I had this with a bit of a spicy meal, so that may have obscured some virtues of it, but I was really disappointed with this.
Very smooth and milky. Way more sweet than bitter.
Great smooth irish whiskey with a nice added flavor from the stout finish.  Very drinkable!

Many people say Jamison missed the mark on this, cant miss a mark when it’s never been done and it was a “let’s see what we get”, completely different and a nice whiskey, if you know how this came to be, you’ll appreciate the whiskey for what it is and you will know what I mean by the “lets see what we get”. For an Irish whiskey it’s nice in my opinion which many will disagree but I also know the story behind this whiskey and how it came to be. Something different for whiskey lovers to try and for a few to appreciate.
Not a bad whiskey but seemed to be an acquired taste. Improved over time but won't be getting another bottle.
bigger and bolder, less sublte then regular

On the nose: Orange/bright fruits, floral notes, oak, vanilla/cream

Front end: Very light, sugary, almost no taste

Middle: Spicy and smooth, slight oiliness, light

Back end: Peppercorn, final hit of heat, but disappears as quickly as it came

Overall, this isn’t a very exciting whiskey and it doesn’t have much complexity, but it is a fairly good sipper.
Chocolate, malt, powdery cocoa, marshmallow, coffee
This is a fantastic whiskey, it has notes of chocolate, coffee, a bit of malt, it's just great.
Like original Jameson with chocolate notes.
Did not pick up as much stout as I would have expected

Before I even nose or taste this, I think it fair to say that I love a good stout beer. I have high hopes this expression will be better than the others I have sampled. 

I sense a subtle spice on the nose. The flavor on the palate has a chocolate note with a subtle wood note. The finish definitely has a small spice punch to it as well. This was not as strong as I had hoped but is my favorite of the series.
Worse then monkey Shoulder. better than bourbon.

nose is light vanilla. taste is a little vanilla corn like bourbons with some char but on the other hand very smooth and light aftertaste like jameson. velvety and oily. Pretty dang good especially for price.

The smell is a bit creamy, malty, strong, bitter, and possibly dark, but this could all be placebo. The initial taste is pretty mellow, but it seems to get more and more mellow, while also allowing the ABV to stand tall. Marshmallow is a very obvious ending to me, after a creamy milky cereal bowl taste combined with a tad of citrus starts the round off. This is an interesting experience to me; although it's been a while since I've had standard Jameson, I know this does not have a similar taste to the classic.
Toda una sorpresa. Gran presencia de notas a chocolate y tostado, muy presentes en las cervezas del estilo stout. Un whisky equilibrado, fácil de beber.

Color is particularly dark for a whiskey, but still clear glossy. Nose is earthy, with notes of prairie grasses and dark chocolate. First sip is very smooth, at first almost hard to perceive. Them subtle cocoa notes arrive, followed by a delicate sprinkling of cinnamon. As I take a second and third sip, earthy notes, perhaps hops, but very subtle and not very bitter, present themselves. The finish is essentially a short linger of the cinnamon and cocoa. The overall flavor is subtle but excellent. I can't help but wish the flavors were just a little stronger. A 90 or 100 proof version would be fantastic.
Truly a tasty whisky. Smooth as silk, rich and warm, with a creamy finish.
Classic Irish biscuit flavours with a dark chocolate finish with a slightly hoppy nose
A lot of alcohol in the nose and a lot of it in the taste. I haven’t find any connection with “stout” in the taste. Very bad aftertaste.
Subtle taste of the stout. Nice flavor
Dusty grass, slightly sweet, finishes with black pepper.
The flavors of Irish ale coming through on this improves Jameson for the better.
Better than Jameson, and the hint of stout makes a very pleasant sipper.
Meget bra med mild smak og søt ettersmak. Den beste jeg har drukket så langt.
The best Jameson I’ve tried. Really digging the flavor. I’m getting a coffee line flavor on the tongue. It’s a great stout flavor.
Very tasty, sweet, smooth and fun just as it should be!  Much better than Jameson reg..

Everything you love about Jameson, with a chocolatey softness

Nose:
Classic green apple and bright malt

There isn’t anything dazzlingly complex. It’s just a really fun-loving enjoyable whiskey.

The first couple glasses were a bit harsh and grainy, but it opened up into a very pleasant Irish with added richness and chocolate malt notes. It does still have that harsh Jameson nose, so I wouldn't recommend drinking it from a Glencairn. This would be a great first whiskey for a non whiskey drinker.

smmmmoooooth
not sure I can feel the IPA

The nose is grassy, with some subtle nuttiness peaking through. Wildflower sweetness makes an appearance with deep breaths.

On the taste more nuttiness comes forward, Hazelnut maybe? Some cocoa depth comes through. Like a biscuit with butter and Nutella?

The finish is very friendly. No burn whatsoever. It's so easy to drink. However, the finish is gone as soon as the whiskey is. Wish it was a bit longer.

Good. Very good. I'll have to replace this bottle when it's gone.

It's a medium amber, definitely dark for a Jameson.

My first impressions of the aroma are banana, followed by cream, vanilla, and caramel.

The taste is tough to place at first, but there are notes of cherry and chocolate that appear at the finish. 

It's a bit complex, but enjoyable. Makes for a nice sipper.
very much overruling taste of milk chocolate which is nice but miss the strong finish
Very easy going and sweet but missing a little depth in taste and finish. Slight aceton on the nose
A bit of a sharp taste on the sides of the young.  Delicious.
My go to when I want a really good chill drink though at $11 a shot is pretty pricey but it’s all about location location. Haha.

Sweet and soft mixed with wood notes. Banana and almond smell are present . Very inviting . Soft to the taste and feels, not
Strong on the first zip , very easy to drink

Chocolate milk on the nose. Kicks in with a bit of bitterness on the palate, reminiscent of coffee or espresso. Finish is smooth but leaves a slight bitterness reminding you of the stout notes; great if you like dark beer.

It needs to breathe! Put it in your glass and let it mellow for half an hour before touching it. It’s sharp and not near as smooth as the original. Def has the choco and roasted notes of a stout. Good experiment - but I don’t think I’ll be buying a bottle when this one is done. Stick to the original.
Smells like a stout. Tastes like a whiskey
My go-to for a week drink.  Always enjoy the taste and smoothness of this bottle

Very unique one.

Taste like a mix of Guinness and Whisky.

Green apple, prune, marzipan, hazelnut, chocolat, coffee 

Delicious
A step above the regular model Jameson
High acetone, a hint of cherry and a bit of shortbread
Floral notes with stout under tones. Caramel and vanilla taste with smoky finish.
Always a smooth and easy drinker. Nothing overpowering, just smooth...

Creamy butterscotch on the nose. Vanilla sugar. Rounded mouthfeel, very slight but pleasant burn. Irish butter, caramels, winter spice on the palate. Long and gentle finish with that butterscotch lingering. Excellent for the price, real easy drinker.
Fantastic for the price - I get it at my local spot for $23
Sweet Irish whiskey up front with chocolate end. Maple and oak tastes in the middle.
Coffee, chocolate, spicy and caramel. A little smoky on the nose. Short finish with caramel.
Caramel and butterscotch with floral hints on the nose. Palate is light, clean, and rounded. Like regular Jameson, but with a fuller rounder profile. A worthwhile upgrade over the standard variety.
This is better than the original.
Jameson with a “creamy” feel. Not tasting much of the stout influence, mostly a texture change.

It's like normal Jameson except good! A lot more complexity on the nose. More dark, chocolate notes coming from it that seems to really round out the original Jameson into something more complex and nice. A little water opens up some nice berry and dark fruit flavors on palate leaving on a surprisingly short finish.
Smooth and subdued. Texture feels thick. Feels warm.
Vanilla and a hint of raspberry on the nose, smooth butterscotch finish
Nose is malted chocolate, silky light cotton candy with a warm finish
So smooth.  Rich and creamy feel.
Rich and full flavor with a light and dry finish. Though to put your finger on but smooth and a bit oaky flavor.
Lots of vanilla and raisin on the tongue with a nice round texture and an apricot finish.
Tomfoolery is a foot, but I enjoy it.
A pleasant scotch with slight stoutish aroma.
Good flavor but not as good as the IPA edition

Nose: Much more lively than you would think, considering this is only 80 proof.  Cocoa, leather.  Dusty books.  Slightly floral - probably from the hops.  Classic Jamo punching through with buttery shortbread, citrus, and herbal notes, but overall more filled out.  Even getting some darker base notes for everything else to stand on.

Palate: Milk chocolate.  Cultured butter.  Orange blossom, honeysuckle, vanilla.  A little tannin and oak coming through.  Mint, orange zest, sweet basil.  Again, presenting as if it were a higher proof while still incredibly easy to drink.  Mouthfeel is medium-light.  Finish is medium-short, leading off with bitter chocolate, orange, mint, and fresh cut grass.  The high and low palate melt away with hints of toasted marshmallow, nutmeg, and graham crackers showing through.  Eventually you're left with a bitter milk chocolate character.

Other notes: Though maybe not as focused as I would've hoped, this shows what a few months of a seasoned barrel can do.  Well executed.
Smooth, vanilla and cream, a little hoppy and a lot of oak. Finish is oak and slight vanilla
Not too complex, it has a dry, clean finish and the stout barrels add a bit of caramel sweetness. Slightly peppery with a drop of water but not overpowering.

Neat.  Nose is pretty as Irish whiskies are.  Honey, apples, floral, touch of hazelnut or macadamia nut.  Taste starts pretty and sweet.  Wildflower honey, vanilla, slight oak..  The stout doesn't show up until the middle end with some hot cocoa and marshmallow.  The finish is tart and sweet, then a final weird funky, bitter molasses or dark treacle that seems to linger for a while

It's a personal taste thing, but this was about 90% great upgrade from standard Jameson, until that weird ending that makes me want to take another sip.  It is pretty smooth and adds some interesting flavors, so this is worth a try for those that don't stomach the standard
Nose is sweet with a faint chocolate and fruit flavor. Slight smoke in tastes, very mild and smooth, but a quick finish.

Creamier than original Jameson with added notes of chocolate

On the nose it's granola and honey. The alcohol is prominent on the taste, leaving more of a burn than you might expect from a mass market whiskey. It's pleasantly sweet, but slightly bland on the taste.

Its so good but it doesn't really have the stout notes that I would expect there's definitely something but not what I expected still a great whiskey
Easy drinking Irish whiskey with a hint of coffee and chocolate stout. Finished the bottle.
This did not disappoint. Enjoyed it neat. Kinda creamy, notes of dark chocolate, and sweet on the finish.

This was on sale and the same price as standard Jameson, so I grabbed a bottle.

Solid whiskey. It’s smell and taste is fuller and richer than the regular version. I don’t get as much of that distinct buttery note on the smell, but it’s nicely melded with the chocolatey flavors. It adds a hint of dark chocolate on the taste with some wood notes and a dry finish. It’s very drinkable and would make a solid every day pour. I’d love to try the IPA version too!
Goes VERY well with Lindt salted dark chocolate. Wouldn't think so, but the brand makes a difference. Lindt mixes the salt, whereas some brands just sprinkle it on. I recommend the mixes.

Nose: very light green apples, milk chocolate and sweet vanilla sugar cookie

Palate: waxy up front and malty through the middle 

Finish: short and sweet mead
Malty, hint of chocolate. Dry finish.

Nose - apple sweetness and chocolate, with hints of coffee
Taste - chocolate and spice, more apple at the end and a touch of hoppy dryness
Finish - spice and hops first, then fades to a lingering sweetness

Nose: frosting, banana cake, and vanilla. A hint of dark roasted notes notes.

Palate: the cake frosting and vanilla. Body is very nice and smooth/a bit oily, making it dessert-like. Some notes of caramel and chocolate.

Finish: a slight bitterness leaves a few notes of chocolate and oak lingering in the finish. But they still feel well-balanced.

All in all a very solid dram that I would love to try at cask strength to see if it can amplify the rich balance of the sweet and bitter notes.

one of the last pours from my year old bottle, it’s another one I would buy again and one I’d buy without a doubt for friends. citrus, vanilla, coconut, cocoa nose. its a sweet vanilla cocoa, citrus, coffee finish.

Vanilla and oak on the nose. Relatively sweet compared to other whiskies I've tried recently. MUCH less alcohol burn, a smoother taste and finish. Not picking up anything related to the stout casks. But very enjoyable, easy drinking.
Didnt get a strong Stout flavour
Wet boot, musty funkiness, raisins and dark dried fruit, coffee grounds, bitter dark chocolate, hoppy. Very smooth, growing spice, lingering dark chocolate flavour.
Smells like stout beer, smooth more viscous than regular Jameson. Stout and Caramel on the finish
Very pleasant, sweet, and sightly fruity on the nose. Mild and easy to drink, sightly bitter with a hint of caramel. Very mild aftertaste.
Finally, bittersweet coffee and metallic hint of dark beer provide a much needed twist to otherwise dull staple.
Not as flavorful as I had expected. Very quick finish.
Strong after taste, not my kind of whiskey

The best Irish whiskey I’ve had yet. YET.
Really nice, smooth, dark, sweet finish. Kind of wish there was more going on up front. But it's different enough to keep on my shelf.
Deliciously smooth Jameson + deliciously smooth stout

As I'm almost done my IPA bottle, I come here to try the stout (first time I had this was 2 years ago when I wasn't crazy about whiskey). This time around, it's delicious. Super silly, smooth and lasting. For me, it has a little less caramel nose than the IPA, but the lasting taste more than makes up for it.
Sweeter than the IPA version. Nose: Butterscotch, dark chocolate, caramel, graham crackers. Palate: Caramel apple, butterscotch Finish: very easy with slight ethanol and pepper on the finish.

Having just tried the Caskmates IPA, I didn't have high hopes for this. BOY, WAS I WRONG. It has such a nice rich chocolate-cream on the nose that it made normal Jameson smell like relatively nothing when I went back for a comparison. The mouthfeel is a lot heavier and a lot more satisfying in my opinion. The taste carries those rich chocolatey notes into your mouth before having a nice black pepper finish that doesn't seem to last long enough. Very good whiskey.
Easy drinking. Pretty light and simple but the stout cask finish livens it up nicely
